awd_titl_txt: Descriptive Dynamics: Group Actions and Their Measured, Borel, and Topological Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
The project lies at the interface of logic and analysis, more specifically, of descriptive set theory, measured group theory, graph theory, ergodic theory, probability theory, and operator algebras. In recent years, mathematicians in these fields have come to realize that problems concerning algebraic, dynamical, and descriptive structural complexity of countable group and equivalence relations can be fruitfully studied via descriptive combinatorial and graph theoretic means. The principal investigator and collaborators have employed this combinatorial perspective to create new tools used to answer several open problems in these fields.  This research project aims to generate more new general tools and to promote fruitful interactions among these fields. 


The PI proposes to study problems around descriptive set theory and its specific interactions with orbit equivalence relations, cocycle superrigidity, treeability, inner amenability, weak equivalence and weak containment, and rigidity/anti-rigidity. The PI's research in these areas has already prompted a wealth of interesting and fundamental questions which intersect a variety of fields including descriptive set theory, measured group theory, graph theory, ergodic theory, probability theory, and operator algebras. Research into these questions will reveal further surprising connections between these fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The PI studied problems around descriptive set theory and its specific interactions with orbit equivalence relations, cocycle superrigidity, treeability, inner amenability, weak equivalence and weak containment, and rigidity/anti-rigidity in the context of measure theoretic and topological dynamics.

The interaction between these ﬁelds is largely catalyzed by a shared interest in orbit equivalence relations arising from group actions on measurable and topological spaces. A unifying phenomenon is that of horizontal interplay between structures: algebraic properties of an acting group are often expressed through dynamical properties of the action, which in turn may be reﬂected through structural properties of the associated orbit equivalence relation. Supplementing this is a vertical interplay between domains: these dynamical and structural properties can manifest at the successively more robust levels of measure, Borel structure, and topology, and thereby facilitate a rich exchange between these three domains.

The results of this project are detailed in 10 different research articles by the PI and his coauthors (two still in preparation and two still awaiting publication at the time of writing).  In addition to submitting to peer-reviewed journals, all of the results and papers have been posted on arxiv.org so that they are freely available to the entire mathematical community. 


Last Modified: 11/30/2023
Modified by: Robin D Tucker-Drob
